top_reviews.review: It's an institution and I'd definitely recommend it. It had a small line going out the door, but it moved quickly. All the staff were lovely and spoke both French and English. The shop is filled to the brim with a great selection of all genres, while also being extremely homey. Shoutout to the lovely girl at cash who was very friendly and nice despite have a lot of people to deal with.

top_reviews.title: Don't miss it!
top_reviews.review: Just go! I had been to Paris many times but never stopped in. It was wonderful and everyone in the place (visitors) obviously love books. The quiet space upstairs was quiet and you could channel the vibe of your favourite author sitting at the typewriter. The books get stamped with a Shakespeare and Co. mark which makes a lovely souvenir for a book you'd buy anyway!

top_reviews.title: Fabulous bookshop
top_reviews.review: The most unique bookstore Iâve ever visited. A wonderful selection and the upstairs reading room is something you cannot skip! You can see and feel the antiquity and historic beauty of not only the building, but the books housed within.

top_reviews.title: Must see for book lovers
top_reviews.review: Loved this bookstore! I love reading, I love history, and I love iconic spots - you get it all here. Be sure to read up on the history of the store before you visit. Purchase a book while you are here and ask for the special wrapping paper. They will wrap it, add a postcard and spray it with perfume. A very nice gift to take home.

top_reviews.title: Worth a stop
top_reviews.review: Really now this historic bookshop is to me just a place to say you been. Expect a line and for it to be very crowded inside. Most of the books are paperbacks and from what I can tell are priced at a premium because they are makes from the shop. Worth a stop if you want to mark it off your Paris list.

top_reviews.title: Loved it!
top_reviews.review: Took my mother and 11 year old daughter here one late afternoon. Waited in the queue for maybe 10 minutes, no big problem there. Itâs not a large bookstore but it is historically significant and has some charm to it. The selection of books in English is quite large and prices were fair. Of course I got The Humpback of Notre Dame! It was a fun experience and they even stamp the inside of your books with their signature logo. Pretty cool.

top_reviews.title: Le Mistral
top_reviews.review: Every time I'm in Paris, I try to come here. It's a great bookstore with a decent inventory and very knowledgeable staff who always manage to be friendly and hospitable, despite my flagrant violation of the photography guidelines when snapping a picture of this book that happens to have my middle name on the cover. I know this is a stop on the tourist route through town, yet it still retains so much charm for me. Give it a go; it's a piece of history, and we're all quite grateful it survived the COVID-19 era.

top_reviews.title: Friendly!
top_reviews.review: If you love books, reading and or writingâ¦ or watched or read anything set in Paris, yiu e heard of this place. Yes, thereâs a line to go in but it moves fast and the people that work there are very nice and helpful! I was hoping they had more used books than they had and they were out of the book I was looking for, but I found another :) And it was by an author I love and somehow had never heard of the book before as it is popular in Europe but not in America! My daughter found a few books too. Plus had to get their cute book tote. Prices were reasonable and I love that they stamp the books as bought there! Make sure to read the signs outside. Live the vibe. Look up a bit of the history of you havenât. Itâs small and a must for readers/writers to stop here!

name: Triumphal Way (Voie Triomphale)
category: Points of Interest & Landmarks Historic Walking Areas

name: Musee De Cluny
description: This museum, located in a spacious former hotel, houses a collection of medieval art, including jewelry, tapestries and sculptures.
getting_there: Cluny â La Sorbonne â¢ 1 min walk

top_reviews.title: Very well presented and fascinating.
top_reviews.review: Well worth the effort to find this museum. Very well organised staffing and display. Take your time here because there is such a variety of different and interesting aspects and items on display. Very enjoyable and stimulating museum.

top_reviews.title: Medieval Art in a Beautiful Setting
top_reviews.review: I have been waiting for this to reopen and so it has! If the Medieval period is fascinating to you, then you will enjoy these exhibits. It was not crowded, the building is beautiful and there are many things to see in here. Without all the people, we could really take our time and enjoy. Perhaps not for the first time visitor, but another one to keep in mind if you have seen the âtop hitsâ.

top_reviews.title: Beautifully curated collection of French medieval art. Lovely Crystal exhibition.
top_reviews.review: The collection is exhibited in 21 galleries, arranged chronologically. If you plan on going soon, do so because there's a wonderful exhibit of crystal objects through the ages on view, including more recent artists such as Albert Giacometti. The medieval French art collection features many masterpieces in a variety of media, including tapestry, sculpture, painting and stained glass. The explanatory text in each room, in both English and French, made it clear that cultural influences from the East were prevalent in several periods. The curators have completed their task with skill and intelligence.

top_reviews.title: Come for the tapestries
top_reviews.review: Centrally located, the Musee de Cluny is the city's premier museum dedicated to medieval art. Most of the artefacts are local. You'll find lots of sculpture and stained glass, notably from Notre Dame and Sainte-Chappelle, among other items. The highlight? The Lady and the Unicorn Tapestries - six massive 15th century tapestries that deservedly have their own room. Take an adventure through the five senses of sight, sound, smell, taste, and touch (just don't touch the tapestries themselves) and wonder who or what is the lady's one desire. Like all museums in Paris, you'll need to go through security to enter.

top_reviews.title: Gallo-Roman remains and Medieval artifacts
top_reviews.review: Set on the site of Gallo-Roman baths from nearly 2,000 years ago, this is an excellent museum on medieval history, namely that of Paris and France. It's a two story museum (lift available) containing many artifacts and remnants from Gallo-Roman times onwards. Excellent displays and the museum is well laid out. Certain displays may be closed or open dependent on the time of year. The outdoor sections are only open when the time is right - usually when the weather is nicer. There's an audio guide available sometimes which is very helpful. You can also arrange a guided tour ahead of time. Gift shop at the end with many books on the subjects covered in the museum. Lockers and bathrooms available on site as well. It's right off of Cluny metro stop and when done at the museum there are plenty of eateries and shops just outside the museum.

top_reviews.title: Must See Museum
top_reviews.review: Paris is home to the Louvre and Musee dâOrsayâ¦.this museum is much smaller and the crowds are much smaller in comparison. It houses great items from the medieval period. Perhaps the most famous piece here are the Lady and the Unicorn tapestries, which are exquisite. Amazing to imagine the level of artistry and hard work that went into creating them! There are also many beautiful pieces of stained glass works and various sculptures/carvings from the period.

top_reviews.title: The Lady and the Unicornâ¦ and so much more
top_reviews.review: I went to the MusÃ©e Cluny on April 7th , which was the first Sunday of the month, so it was free, but luckily was no line at all. I started with the exhibit at the Frigidarium or the Thermes de Cluny. The walls are behind the exhibits now, so I wasnât able to see the ruins of the Gallo-Roman thermal baths discovered right in the heart of Paris. I have no regrets though because the exhibitâThe Art of France at the time of Charles VIIâ was spectacular. It was fascinating to see how the paintings, objects of art, stained glass windows, tapestries have changed from static and expressionless to lively and meaningful over the course of 39 years, from 1422 to 1461. Then I continued to the permanent collection where elaborate craftsmanship of the medieval time was presented in the best possible way. Intricate carvings of wooden, silver and ivory objects, brightly colored stained glass (you can get a close look at the examples of stained glass from the Sainte-Chapelle), opulent religious objects, original statuary from the Notre Dame Cathedral, etc. And stunning tapestriesâ¦ not just The Lady and the Unicorn, which is just beyond any reasonable imagination. I donât even know how much time I spent looking at these six stunning tapestries. Five of them depict the five senses â taste, hearing, sight, smell, and touch. The sixth displays the words "Ã mon seul dÃ©sir" (to my only/sole desire). Once in your life you have to see this treasureâ¦ reallyâ¦ Practical note: the earlier you come on a free Sunday of the month the better: when I exited the museum around 2pm, the line to enter was very long.

top_reviews.title: Lovely place
top_reviews.review: Calm, beautiful, ancient place with some lovely Medieval treasures. This museum has quite recently re-opened after a period of being closed and the whole space has been sensitively and expertly updated. My only issue was with the lockers. They operate with a system where the user sets a combination code to lock them. The code is set afresh by the user each time they are used. When I went to get a locker, I found I was opening several unlocked lockers with other people's stuff in them. Didn't happen with all of them, but did happen with about half of the ones I tried. Eventually I found an empty locker. I set the 4-digit combination code. You have to key it in twice. I didn't get it wrong. Yet when I returned to collect my stuff, the lock wouldn't open - it didn't like the combination I tried. A security guard, happily, opened the locker for me.

top_reviews.title: For the medieval art!
top_reviews.review: The gothic building is magnificent and the collection is stunning. The terms rooms are spacious and fresh where you can see beautiful remains and sculptures. The chapel is a must see, and also the famous Unicorn tapestries. There's so many treasures to admire. On the top of that the temporary exhibitions are exquisite. A must see while in Europe! Unmissable!

top_reviews.title: Overlooked gem
top_reviews.review: A lovely gem with an old Roman bath excavation, statues, stained glass, the tapestry with the woman and the unicorn, and more! Such an overlooked spot but worth your while! And not too busy. But close walk to Shakespeare and Co Bookstore, Notre-Dame and more. Get the museum pass so you can go to little gems like this for free!

name: BT-Transfer
description: Private Airport Transfers in Paris , Specialists in transfer to eurodisney providing free booster seats & baby seats. We would also like to inform you that we are Pet Friendly book your transfer now and pay upon arrival... most dependable and experienced team in Paris

top_reviews.title: BT Transfers a must for any visitors to Paris
top_reviews.review: We arranged a pick up from Gard de Nord to our hotel in the 7th. We were very thankful as the crowds outside the train station was very overwhelming. We then booked a transfer from our hotel to the airport a week later. We were a family of 4 with 4 large suitcases so they provided a van for us. Both times the vehicles were clean and modern. The drivers were friendly and always on time. I would definitely recommend BT Transfers for any visitors to Paris.

top_reviews.title: Reliable Transfer / Helpful Driver
top_reviews.review: Once I did confirm w B&T our transfers went very smoothly. I hadnt heard from them so I did check before our flight pick up at CDG; but they got back to me straight away and reassured us a driver would be there for us. We decided to book transfer back to airport as well considering the rate was reasonable and we needed a reliable ride. We will definetely use B&T again.

top_reviews.title: Easy to use service
top_reviews.review: I booked through their website and I got an email shortly after asking me to confirm the details which I did. In the email they tell you your price which should be paid in cash at the drop off point so be prepared for that. The driver shows up at the airport with your name on their phone. We arrived a little earlier and exited a little earlier than expected so I waited by the airport gate exit and would check the names every now and then. The driver we got was professional and helpful. I would recommend this service for tourist who may have larger luggages that would be difficult to get around in the metro. I was also contacted by WhatsApp by the driver which I appreciated as I did not have my phone number active abroad but still had access to WhatsApp!

top_reviews.title: Would totally recommend and use it again!
top_reviews.review: I booked a round trip for me and my friend from Paris Beauvais Airport to Disneyland Paris with BT-Transfer and I'd do it again. The website is simple and the process to reserve a car is clear and fast. If you need more information you can send them an email and they respond fast, professionally and kindly (a special thanks to Rozanne, who answered all my emails). The driver Kamal was the best! He was on time both times, he was so welcoming, polite and fun (and a very good driver too). Overall I had an amazing experience with this company and their service, totally recommend!

top_reviews.title: Trustworthy and safe, I highly recommend
top_reviews.review: I have used BT Transfer several times to pick me up at CDG, most recently this past week in October 2023. Last year they drove me from Paris to the Loire Valley. Every driver is very professional, punctual, but most importantly safe. I trust them over and over for my transportation needs. The vehicles are impeccably clean, and they always have water waiting for you. Wonderful little detail to help you rehydrate after a long flight.

top_reviews.title: Reliable transportaion service!
top_reviews.review: We traveled to Europe for 3 weeks and used BT-Transfer on 3 separate occasions. 2 were for a pick up from the airport and the driver was waiting for us just as described in the reservation confirmation. The last occasion was for transportation to to the airport and the driver arrived 10 minutes before the scheduled pick up. Very professional drivers and reliable transportation service. Would definitely use BT-Transfer again.

top_reviews.title: Great Shuttle service in Paris
top_reviews.review: We used BT transfer to get from CDG airport to our hotel - Relais Spa Val d'Europe, we used them both ways and were very happy with the service provided. We traveled with two kids 7 and 4yrs old and there were car seats waiting for them in the car. Driver was waiting for us on the airport and was very helpful. Smooth and pleasant drive to the hotel. Similar experience with the way back to the airport. Would recommend to anyone and use in the future any time we are back in Paris.

top_reviews.title: Excellent reliable service
top_reviews.review: We have used BT transfer on both our recent trips to Paris. Each time they are waiting at airport with a clear sign for our party. Escorts us short walk to where they are parked and takes us to exact location as requested. We have also used on return journey to airport and been picked up right outside Disney after a full day there! The drivers are always pleasant and assist us with luggage. Fantastic service. Will definitely use again!

top_reviews.title: 5 Stars!
top_reviews.review: I booked 2 trips with BT transfers - collection from the airport with a tour of Paris and a return journey to the airport. Both times the drivers were on time and very courteous. Our first driver, Thilak, took us to 4 attractions on our tour which was great. The traffic was crazy but he navigated it well, I wouldnât have wanted to drive in it! Would definitely recommend BT transfers - especially the tour of Paris if youâre heading to Disney!

top_reviews.title: Exceptional!
top_reviews.review: My trip was with family and friends, we all flew out from different parts of the country and all used BT-Transfer. Collectively, our experience was outstanding! I highly recommend BT-Transfer to anyone travelling to Paris. The process was easy, and the driver/company was professional and exceptional every step of the way. I will see you again in a few years BT-Transfer!! : ) Soto/Cardona/Figueroa family!

name: Palais Garnier
description: This opulent 19th-century opera house is known for its magnificent interiors and the amazing performances by the Paris Opera Ballet.
address: Place de lâOpÃ©ra entrance at the corner of Scribe and Auber streets, 75009 Paris France

top_reviews.title: Get the audio guide
top_reviews.review: My partner and I came to explore the beauty of the palais, but we ended up having a wonderful visual history lesson thanks to the audio guide. It's completely worth the extra fee if you are interested in the storytelling and history. Of course the palais is gorgeous. Mind-blowingly opulent and reminiscent of living your best Phantom of the Opera fantasy.

top_reviews.title: The Beauty of Palais Granier
top_reviews.review: Enjoyed the beauty of the Opera House, also the information about the tie in to the Phantom of the Opera. Amazing opulence of the Opera House, the mirrored rooms looking on forever. The Box of the Phantom of the Opera.

top_reviews.title: Go early to avoid crowds
top_reviews.review: Palais Garnier is an opera house that still holds performances today. It was so cool to see all of the intricate details, and over course the grand stairs. Tickets are 15 euros per person and we purchased it on site. We came on a Friday at around noon, and there were a good amount of people there. But it wasn't as crowded as other Paris tourist attractions, like the museums. They have rooms with art pieces so if you are an art buff, you should allot yourself time for that too. Neither I nor my husband are art buffs but we did want to see the architecture. It took us less than an hour to walk through, explore, and take pictures. I wish we came earlier to avoid the crowds, so if you visit, that's what I would recommend.

top_reviews.title: A glittering masterpiece of lavish splendor
top_reviews.review: This magnificent theater is a sumptuous sight to behold. From its glittering chandeliers to its lavish dÃ©cor, this is one of Paris' most stunning attractions. Whether you're attending a performance or just taking in the grandeur, Palais Garnier is sure to take your breath away.

top_reviews.title: Wonderful palace
top_reviews.review: The Opera Garnier is a stunning masterpiece of architecture and art. The grand staircase, the lavish auditorium, and the magnificent ceiling painted by Chagall are breathtaking. The guided tour was informative and entertaining. A must-see for anyone who loves opera, ballet, or history.

top_reviews.title: Magnificent
top_reviews.review: This architectural marvel was a real highlight of my first trip to Paris. Entry wasnât too expensive, and thereâs a fair bit to see. The grand staircase is the showpiece but there are a few other rooms and the theatre itself, as well as displays about shows that have been put on there

top_reviews.title: An ornamental masterpiece!
top_reviews.review: This iconic opera house is a must-see when visiting Paris. Its ornamental architecture and grandeur are breathtaking, with a gleaming interior that will leave you in awe. Its monumental size and beauty are a testament to the city's cultural history. A must-see for any traveler!

top_reviews.title: An amazing experience at the Ballet 12/31/2023
top_reviews.review: I went here for the 12/31 ballet performance. First of, wow, what an amazing place. I am back in New York and still amaze at the beauty of this place. The performance was great, I really recommend everyone to attend the ballet or the opera at least once in their lives. Although black tie was not required, everyone dressed beautifully which gave it a touch of elegance, and made it more special New Years Eve. I will assume this was because of NYE or because this was the last performance, the few champagne and small snacks were really a very nice touch as well:

top_reviews.title: Beautiful place but overrun with âsocial media creatorsâ
top_reviews.review: This building is beyond beautiful . Every room just is breath taking. The self absorbed people making social media content almost ruins it. You simply just can not ignore it. They take up so much space for their photo shoot or even dancing. Theyre ruining the experience for people who are there for the actual history .

top_reviews.title: Take a Tour or Attend a Performance
top_reviews.review: This is the 19th Century opera house, a major feature of the renovation of the old city. The outside is ornate and exquisite. There are 2 ways to see the inside: You can take a tour, or you can attend a concert. Most of the performances are of dance, and I recommend attending a show. The staircase is grand and should be walked during an intermission.

name: Jardin des Tuileries
description: Located within the Place de la Concorde, this garden demonstrates the Parisian style of intricate landscaping.
address: Pl. de la Concorde, 75001 Paris France

top_reviews.title: Beautiful well kept gardens
top_reviews.review: What a nice garden! The grounds are huge. It connects the Musee de l'Orangerie and the Louvre. After we saw the line for Musee de l'Orangerie was way too long, we decided to ditch those plans and stroll through the garden instead. It was around 11 am on a Wednesday and there were so many people sitting by the fountains. Made me wonder if they had work or not, or if French people just know how to enjoy life. There was also some kind of summer carnival going on at the time (mid-August) complete with food vendors, and some pretty impressive temporary amusement park rides. The grounds are well kept and the park is clean. I could definitely see me having some picnics here if I was a local. Overall, great spot for a break from city life and enjoy some fresh air.

top_reviews.title: November - not a good time to go
top_reviews.review: ... as there is little to see. Sure the sculptures / copies are very well kept (though one depicting a sea god with accompanying cherubs many of whom have lost their heads literally) but the gardens are bare and the sandy paths are puddled. People were trying to make the best of it sitting on wet chairs at the side of pools of water around fountains.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful!
top_reviews.review: Stunning and we had a beautiful day to enjoy this park. We came across it when walking from the Louvre which is right beside it. Found a nice spot to get a glass of wine and watch the world go by. Beautiful and well worth a walk around after visiting the Louvre.

top_reviews.title: A Green Break
top_reviews.review: A huge garden next to the Louvre, named for the tile workshop that was here prior to the 18th Century. The big garden is full of sculpture and art, as well as fountains. Lots of people come here for a green break, even in cold weather. When it is warm, all sorts of flowers are in bloom.

top_reviews.title: Perfect place for a coffee stroll âï¸
top_reviews.review: It would be best if you visit the garden during spring or summer, as it will be more vibrant. We when there two times, but it was cloudy and part of garden were not accessible as they were renovating. The place is really beautiful and I recommend to visit it in the morning. Itâs close to the Louvre, MusÃ©e dâOrsay and MusÃ©e de l'Orangerie.

name: 1st Arrondissement
description: Situated principally on the right bank of the River Seine, it also includes the west end of the Ãle de la CitÃ©. The arrondissement is one of the oldest in Paris, the Ãle de la CitÃ© having been the heart of the city of Lutetia, conquered by the Romans in 52 BC, while some parts on the right bank (including Les Halles) date back to the early Middle Ages. It is the least populated of the city's arrondissements and one of the smallest by area, a significant part of which is occupied by the Louvre Museum and the Tuileries Gardens. Much of the remainder of the arrondissement is dedicated to business and administration.
address: Entre Rues Etienne Marcel, des Petits Champs, Daniele Casanova, des Capucines et Quais des Tuileries, Francois Miterrand, du Louvre, de La Megisserie, 75001 Paris France
getting_there: Palais Royal â MusÃ©e du Louvre â¢ 5 min walk

name: PanthÃ©on
description: With the Pantheon, architect Jacques-Germain Soufflot met Louis XVâs wish to glorify the monarchy in the form of a church dedicated to Saint GeneviÃ¨ve, the patron saint of Paris. The edifice was deconsecrated during the Revolution in 1791 and renamed the Pantheon. During the turbulent years of the 19th century, as regimes changed, it alternated in its role as a religious and patriotic monument. Since 1885, the year of Victor Hugoâs death and burial in the Pantheon, it has been the last resting place for the great writers, scientists, generals, churchmen and politicians who have made the history of France. The crypt houses the tombs of more than 70 illustrious figures including Voltaire, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Emile Zola, Alexandre Dumas, Pierre and Marie Curie etc.Open:> 1st April to 30th September: from 10 a.m. to 6.30 p.m.> 1st October to 31st March: from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Last admission 45 minutes before closing time. Closed:> 1st January, 1st May and 25th December. Admission fees: Adults : 8,5â¬; Concessions (18 to 25) = 5,50 â¬; Free admission: minors under 18*; Free admission: 18-25 years old* (citizens of one of the 27 countries of the EU or are non-European permanent residents of France) * excluding school groups

top_reviews.title: Worth a visit, maybe budget 2 hrs
top_reviews.review: Enjoyed going to the Pantheon, would recommend going once. The staff were all very nice. The audio guide is worth it as it has a lot of info, although had no earbuds so you constantly have to hold it up to your ear like a phone, it gets a tad tiring. The crypt was solemn and it was nice to pay my respects. Marie Curie and Victor Hugo are both laid to rest there, along with many others. I'd recommend spending 2hrs tops at the Pantheon.

top_reviews.title: Paris Pantheon Must See
top_reviews.review: My son (16) and I enjoyed the Pantheon. This was my 4th time to Paris and his first. I bought tickets about 2 months in advance. The Pantheon contains the tombs of Marie and Pierre Curie, Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas, and Voltaire. (Paris-pantheon.fr). There are also beautiful paintings of Joan of Arc, Charlemagne being crowned by the Pope, and many more. A definite must see for history and art lovers.

top_reviews.title: Imposing monument to French heroes
top_reviews.review: Paris has so many monumental buildings that the Pantheon seems like just one more huge, domed edifice. This baroque structure celebrates famous French people, many of whom are buried here, like enlightenment figures Voltaire and Rousseau. Three famous authors are buried in one small crypt. Thereâs also Focaultâs pendulum that demonstrates the Earthâs rotation, and special art installations and an exhibit on a French resistance martyr.

top_reviews.title: The Pantheon is impressive as well as insightful - if not on your list, you may want to consider!
top_reviews.review: The Pantheon was less hectic when we went at about midday. The Pantheon has many information screens, and you also have the audio guides available too. This started as Christian Basilica and then transformed into the National Pantheon. Underneath is the crypts, which have the bodies of generals, dignitaries, scientists, and bodies of those honoured during the wars. It has the history of the 22 men, and 1 woman was condemned to death by the Germans in 1944. You can pay a small amount to walk the 203 steps to the top. It's a great spot for photos across Paris. It is lovely and cool with seating spread out around the inside.

top_reviews.title: The crypt is amazing
top_reviews.review: The Pantheon is an amazing place to visit. Go early in the day before the crowds build up. It is a temple established back in the Revolution and dedicated to distinguished French citizens. The crypt contains the remains of Voltaire - but not his heart - and those of other famous French people including Victor Hugo and Madame Curie. (There are many more men than women). The sculpture and wall paintings are out of this world. The entry fee is not cheap but well worth it.

top_reviews.title: Outstanding
top_reviews.review: Wow!!!! This place is absolutely stunning, it's impressive from the outside but as soon as you walk in it takes your breath away. Thwr3 was an option for a further tour but sadly it was sold out when we visited but worth every penny to look around inside.

name: Luxembourg Gardens
description: Luxembourg Gardens is a charming oasis in the heart of Paris, loved by both locals and travelers alike. With 55 acres of manicured gardens, it's the perfect place to unwind and soak up the Parisian atmosphere. You can admire the beautifully arranged flower beds, towering trees, and the grand Luxembourg Palace which overlooks the gardens. In the summer, the park is great for picnics and family outings. Be sure to check out the pÃ©tanque (lawn bowling) and chess areas, too. To learn more about the park's rich history, consider joining a walking tour of the gardens. â Tripadvisor
address: Rue de MÃ©dicis Rue de Vaugirard, 75006 Paris France

top_reviews.title: A place to while away some time
top_reviews.review: Large public park with lots of chairs to sit in and enjoy people and bird watching. Lots of ponds and fountains with plenty of water fowl and parakeets. Various food outlets that you can either eat on or take away. You can hire a model boat for one of the ponds.

top_reviews.title: Well-crafted sale boats for the boating pond.
top_reviews.review: Hiring boats at the boating pond was probably the highlight of our seven year old's trip to Paris. It has us all smiling, waiting to see which way the wind would take the boat. The play area was good too.

top_reviews.title: Great Experience for us
top_reviews.review: Ideal for a stroll in Paris in the early morning or late afternoon. A brief reprieve from the commotion and clamour of the metropolis. Because of its position in the midst of Paris and the fact that it is in the Latin Quarter, it is an excellent site to make a brief halt in order to rest your feet after taking a lengthy stroll around the lovely Latin neighbourhood. The cathedral of Notre Dame, the Pantheon, and the Seine river are all within a few minutes' walking distance from one another.

top_reviews.title: A grandiose display of statues and fountains
top_reviews.review: The Luxembourg Gardens are a grandiose display of statues, fountains, and lush greenery. It's the perfect place to take a leisurely stroll and admire the breathtaking beauty of the gardens. From the grandiose fountain in the center to the statues of famous figures, the gardens are a sight to behold. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a peaceful and picturesque spot.

top_reviews.title: Tranquil Haven in Paris
top_reviews.review: Luxembourg Gardens is a tranquil oasis in the heart of Paris. The manicured lawns, serene fountains, and vibrant flowers create a perfect escape. Whether you're strolling through the gardens or relaxing by the pond, it offers a serene respite from the city's hustle and bustle. A must-visit for a moment of tranquility.

top_reviews.title: Parisian elegance
top_reviews.review: This classy garden is an oasis in the heart of Paris. Unfortunately we didnât stay long as we ended up visiting on one of the hottest days of the year, but we saw enough to see how well kept it was, particularly the flowers. Really recommend

top_reviews.title: Lovely, even in February
top_reviews.review: Walked round here and everything was very neat and pretty even though it was a cold February day. Lots of chairs to sit, places to get a coffee and chairs everywhere. I bet itâs fabulous in the summer.

top_reviews.title: My happy place in Paris
top_reviews.review: For the umpteenth time, I had such a lovely morning walk in my happy place, the Jardin du Luxembourgâ¦ same beauty, same tranquility, same charm as always. I have been in Paris many times but walking on the leafy alleys of one of the most beautiful parks in the world has never been missed. Love everything there: exquisite statuary, beautiful pond, relaxing atmosphereâ¦ this is Parisâ¦

top_reviews.title: Beautiful public gardens
top_reviews.review: These huge public gardens are located in front of the Luxembourg palace. There are sculptures, fountains and manicured hedges. They are much less crowded than the Tuileries gardens near the Louvre, and I found the Luxembourg gardens even more beautiful, too.

top_reviews.title: Luxembourg Garden a must visit place in Paris
top_reviews.review: This is a huge public gardens located in front of the Luxembourg palace. There are sculptures, fountains and manicured hedges. A sprawling location with ample space to hangout or enjoy the nature. A must visit while at Paris. I really liked the Luxembourg gardens beauty at it's best

name: Left Bank (Rive Gauche)
description: The section of Paris south of the River Seine.
category: Historic Sites Neighborhoods Historic Walking Areas

name: Musee Carnavalet - Histoire de Paris
description: The Carnavalet Museum is dedicated to the history of Paris and its inhabitants and has collections illustrating the evolution of the city from prehistory through to the present day. A vast array of works of art, relics and models are displayed in 100 or so rooms, showing the capital at various periods in history and evoking intellectual and everyday life. Magnificent restored historical scenery creates an evocative setting for a stroll through the centuries in an enriching, delightful visitor experience.

top_reviews.title: Surprisingly amazing museum
top_reviews.review: Museum of the history of Paris. I allocated 1.5 hours. Do yourself a favor and don't limit it. There's so much here. I learned a lot about the French revolution, and feel like I can now make sense of it. The art nouveau section was great -even more photogenic than the in the Orsay. By that time I was running out of time. I'd go back again, especially since it's free.

top_reviews.title: History of the world in Paris
top_reviews.review: I didnt expect a lot from here, i thought it jus something free to do, boy was i wrong. If you have to choose just a handful of the dozens of museums, free and paid the Paris has make sure this is one of them. The history of the world is traced inside this one museum as it unfolded in what is now Paris. From acient rome artifacts, to medieval tapestres to the rise and fall of their monarchy, you can take a trip through the history of Paris from inception to the 21st century

top_reviews.title: Fascinating Museum
top_reviews.review: We were staying in a lovely little hotel a few corners away (Villa Beaumarchais) and just happened to be walking by. We decided to take a look and ended up spending almost 4 hours veiwing the exhibits spanning multiple floors of this gorgeous former private mansion. We could have stayed even longer (but you can probably go through quicker than we did and still learn a lot). The history of Paris is well presented: maps, scale model displays, artifacts, art, interesting descriptions. Very much worth a visit.

top_reviews.title: A must
top_reviews.review: Totally recommended. The best way to begin to understand Paris before you see it. There are many extraordinary rooms from seventeenth and eighteenth century houses that help one feel what was once inside these ancient buildings. The craftsmanship in the carved, painted and decorated walls was what I liked most. It also takes you on a powerful and not too long journey through the revolution (although Iâll never quite understand it and all its factions).

top_reviews.title: Great visit, but a bit confusing!
top_reviews.review: The museum is incredible, located in an ancient hotel, and is free to visit. It tells the story of Paris, from prehistoric times until the 21st century. The museum is very big, and very interesting, but it is organised in a way that there is a right course to follow, and if you turn on the wrong corridor or enter the wrong room, the timeline doesnât make sense anymore.

top_reviews.title: Renovated and Expanded
top_reviews.review: It's been closed for a while, and while closed it was expanded and renovated. Now there is more to see and the display is more open and easier to follow. Lots of treasures here as they have an extensive collections of objects from the history of the city way back to pre-Roman times. And it's free!

top_reviews.title: Hidden gem
top_reviews.review: Wonderful musuem on the history of Paris, with free entrance. Although not well known, this museum provides a great perspective of the history of Paris, from the early settlements, to the great Kings and the French Revolution. Definitely not to miss.

top_reviews.title: Must-see history of Paris
top_reviews.review: Beat the crowds with this hidden gem and learn the history of Paris, as experienced by the rich and famous. Lots of recreated rooms, artifacts, and art, including an exhibit honoring the 1924 Paris Olympics. And itâs free!

top_reviews.title: Must see museum
top_reviews.review: Excellent museum and a favorite of our time in Paris. Free, beautifully curated, presentations fit for adults and kids. Laid out chronologically, we only made it through mid 1700s in 1.5 hours, will return to see the remaining 1.5 floors on next trip. Highly recommend.

top_reviews.title: Definitely worth a visit
top_reviews.review: Surprisingly large museum given that itâs free to enter, so so many rooms! Loved that there were staged rooms with even the ceilings done. Could be confusing to get around with so many rooms but thereâs signs to help.

name: Boulevard St. Germain
description: This historic street is most famous for its assortment of old cafÃ©s.

name: Jardin du Palais Royal
description: A beautiful garden dating back to the French Revolution.
getting_there: Palais Royal â MusÃ©e du Louvre â¢ 4 min walk

name: L'Horizon de Kheops - Paris Bercy
address: 45 Rue Des Pirogues De Bercy, 75012 Paris France

name: Medici Fountain
description: This fountain in the Luxembourg Gardens is a popular destination for local students.
address: Rue de MÃ©dicis Luxembourg Garden, 75006 Paris France

name: Le DÃ´me des Invalides
description: This impressive domed church, built in 1793, is located next to the HÃ´tel des Invalides.
address: 129 Rue de Grenelle HÃ´tel national des Invalides, 75007 Paris France

top_reviews.title: Best to go when not many tourist groups are there, and before the Army Museum
top_reviews.review: Before going into the Army Museum, we went to the Dome to see Napoleon's tomb, fortunately before a large group of tourists. It can be quite noisy in the Dome, so best to go when there are not many people there. It does not take much time to visit the Dome - it is worth going to the ground level to look at the reliefs on the wall of Napoleon's civic accomplishments.

top_reviews.title: Napoleonâs tomb
top_reviews.review: A ticket to Les Invalides includes admission to the army museum and the Dome, under which Napoleonâs casket is located. This soaring dome is elaborately decorated, and the Emperor is in a huge black stone casket. There are other similar structures in Paris like the Pantheon, but itâs one of those iconic Paris sites you want to try to see.

top_reviews.title: Quite impressive for a tomb
top_reviews.review: The dome is quite impressive to mark napoleonâs tomb, but seems like such a waste of resources. Donât get me wrong, it is very beautiful and the alter inside is quite ordained and impressive. Iâm glad I visited.

name: Sensation Spa
description: Sensation spa. In the heart of the 7th arrondissement, near the Eiffel Tower and the Invalides. We care of great qualities prestations. Relaxing massages, wellness massages, world massage, deep tissue massage. Massage rituals. Massage and body scrub. Hair removal and shaving for men. Gym with private coaching. We have a sauna, steam bath and aromatic jacuzzi. Our masseurs and masseuses are at your disposal to advise you and allow you to choose the treatment best suited to your needs

name: Musee du quai Branly - Jacques Chirac
description: Located close to the Eiffel Tower, the musÃ©e du quai Branly exhibits 3 500 works of art from Africa, the Americas, Asia and Oceania. This important collection makes the musÃ©e du quai Branly an unmissable place for discovering the art culture of the non-European world. The museumâs original and imposing architecture designed by Jean Nouvel and its wild garden created by the landscaper Gilles ClÃ©ment combine to make it a pleasant and unique place. The museum is the fourth largest museum in Paris.
breadcrumbs: Musee du quai Branly - Jacques Chirac

Alma â Marceau â¢ 7 min walk

name: Rue Cler
category: Points of Interest & Landmarks Flea & Street Markets

name: Towers of Notre-Dame Cathedral
description: A visit of the Towers of Notre Dame de Paris, built from 1160 in the Flamboyant Gothic style, gives visitors a close-up view of the Cathedral's flying buttresses, spires and roofs. Gargoyles and chimeras adorn the outer gallery of the North Tower with its ribbed vaulting and spiral staircase, while the South Tower houses the belfry and Emmanuel, the great bourdon bell. The upper gallery provides magnificent views of Paris, the Seine and the succession of bridges across the river. Designated world heritage site by UNESCO.Open:> 1st April to 30th September: from 10 a.m. to 6.30 p.m.> From July to August on Saturday and Sunday: until 11 p.m. (evenings).> 1st October to 31st March: from 10 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. Last admission 45 minutes before closing time.Closed:> 1st January, 1st May and 25th December.Admission fees: Adults : 8,5â¬; Concessions (18 to 25) = 5,50 â¬; Free admission: minors under 18*; Free admission: 18-25 years old* (citizens of one of the 27 countries of the EU or are non-European permanent residents of France) * excluding school groups

St-Michel â Notre-Dame â¢ 4 min walk

top_reviews.title: Still under Construction ~ can't go in!
top_reviews.review: Since 2019's fire Norte Dame has been under Construction and you will not be able to go inside. You can go onto the grounds and watch the construction even sit down on the large Bleachers that they have in front of the Cathedral for visitors to sit/relax/ and watch from. There is a large 8' fence up but you can still see a majority of the building and it's gargoyles.

top_reviews.title: Of course it's excellent but here are some tips:
top_reviews.review: Of course it's excellent. But of course you know it's under construction until possibly 2025 or Late 2024. However, there is a TON of information about what happened and what IS happening right now for reconstruction on the walls surrounding the construction. I HIGHLY recommend going down into the under story which cost about 9 Euro in order to 1. learn about the Cathedral and Paris and 2. to support their endeavors in reconstruction. FYI: No bathrooms in the vicinity. Go to a pay toilet or cafe before arrival.

top_reviews.title: Still under construction but..
top_reviews.review: Visited in January 2024 The construction works are still ongoing an there is no entry into the interior but there are a lot of information of the restoration works and history about the cathedral scattered around the front of the cathedral. It is free to stop by and appreciate the exterior. The side and back are unfortunately blocked off at the time of visit.

name: MusÃ©e de lâOrangerie
description: Most famous for its display dedicated to Monet's Water Lilies, this gallery in the Tuileries Gardens has a wide collection of impressionist and post-impressionist works.
address: Jardin des Tuileries - Cote Seine Place de la Concorde, 75001 Paris France

top_reviews.title: Very nice specialty collection
top_reviews.review: 11/11/23 Had a wonderful visit. While not the largest museums, we definitely enjoyed the exhibits which include Monet, Utrillo, Modigliani, Renoir and other items of collector Paul Guillaume. We did not have tickets and had to wait. However it was a cool dry day and the wait wasnât more than about 15 min on a Saturday morning around 10:30am. People in front of us may have been there quite awhile longer as a few of them left and it was just minutes later that several of us in line were allowed in to by tickets, which were only 11 Euro each. Many museums including this one do require security screening but this only took a couple of minutes.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful museum, book time slot in advance
top_reviews.review: The museum is in beautiful surroundings. The main attraction is the Water lilies which are nicely displayed. The Modigliani exhibition is worth, too. Please do book a time slot online to avoid standing in a long queue. Worth booking well in advance as slots sell out.

top_reviews.title: The Water Lillies
top_reviews.review: The Water Lillies is what you're here for and the 4 big ones here do not disappoint. They are staged in large viewing rooms that should allow you to see everything. This is a popular sight so we came at opening with our Paris Pass in hand as well as a reservation to avoid hassle. I would recommend taking the time to get a reservation on their website if you can, the non-reservation line is long and it could take some time to get in unless you arrive early.

top_reviews.title: Superb Modigliani exhibit. Beautifully designed museum, world-class.
top_reviews.review: We loved the Monet Water Lilies, of course, but the hit for us was seeing so many beautiful paintings by Utrillo and Modigliani (the special exhibition when we were there). The rooms are perfectly designed with the paintings of usually and sometimes two master impressionists. So you can enjoy the work in comparison with other pieces by the artist. Superb collection, excellent curated. And the interior design of the museum is world-class: so easy to find your way through the rooms. Perfect museum experience.

top_reviews.title: A must-see for art lovers
top_reviews.review: MusÃ©e de l'Orangerie Paris is a must-see for art lovers, as it houses some of Monet's most famous masterpieces, such as his Water Lilies series. The museum is a popular destination for tourists and art aficionados alike, offering an unforgettable experience. Highly recommended!

top_reviews.title: Superbly designed museum
top_reviews.review: This museum is perfectly designed for Monetâs masterpieces. These are truly astounding works of art, and the museum provides ample space in which to study them. It is pretty busy and too many people are trying to take selfies to the detriment of those who actually want to study the art, but this doesnât take away from the magic of seeing Monetâs talent up close

top_reviews.title: Go Early for the best experience
top_reviews.review: Interesting museum designed for Monetâs Water Lillies masterpieces. The perfect setting for artwork of this scale. Go early to be able to study the art before the room is crowded with tourists taking selfies in front of the paintings, blocking your views. Beautiful lighting and perfect setting in the Tuileries Gardens. Near Plaza de Concorde (Obelisk) and nice view of the Eiffel Tower from the cue.

top_reviews.title: You MUST visit
top_reviews.review: Monets are SUPERB. Cezannes and Renoirs excellent. Not sure of the value of the special exhibition of Modigliani however, as he didn't seem to be able to paint. Very well set out. Easily able to get close to the paintings and also good perspective from a distance. Queue management was poor: had to queue for an hour in near zero temperatures but it was worth it

top_reviews.title: Worth a quick visit
top_reviews.review: We made a very brief visit here, spent just one hour taking in the huge water lilies by Monet. No doubt, they are impressive. But we did not feel that we were rushed here spending just one hour - it felt like the right amount of time. Admittedly, we must have been maxed out on museums, having visited Louvre and Orsay previously ( yes, we actually did that !)

top_reviews.title: Meditative and spiritual experience - sublime
top_reviews.review: Mnet will always be one of the greatest artists of all time and his Water Lilies are his ultimate creation. The museum does them a great service by asking visitors to respect silence and meditative experience. It was sublime.
